Al Jolson.Action: Encourages audience participation enthusiastically, offers humorous and friendly encouragement to sing along.
Points to the exit jokingly when audience refuses to sing, using humor rather than hostility.
Shows appreciation and admiration for Asa's shy singing by stopping to listen quietly and applauding with the audience.
Performs confidently in front of an audience despite initial shyness, sings the chorus again when encouraged, receives enthusiastic applause.
Appears shy and almost embarrassed after performing, hesitant to admit background in show business, stammers slightly when mentioning the synagogue.
Supports a young boy with talent, tries to reassure the boy's parents about his care and opportunities.
Respects the boy's parents' wishes even when disappointed, gracefully withdraws without confrontation.
Asa confidently stands up in the balcony and starts singing despite others waiting for someone else to begin, showing initiative and self-assurance.
Shows awareness of the group's hesitation and takes action to overcome it, indicating social understanding and leadership potential.
Is described as running away repeatedly, suggesting evasiveness or lack of responsibility in some contexts.
When his singing voice breaks and audience laughs, he quickly adapts by whistling flawlessly, turning the moment around and impressing everyone.
Feels dejected and wants to quit after his voice breaks during the performance.
Encourages Asa by praising his whistling and reassuring him that the change is temporary; holds Asa’s shoulders and offers him a partnership with billing.
Eagerly wants to try singing in the middle of the act despite Steve's protest, showing openness and enthusiasm.
Greets the old man backstage warmly with 'Hello, Pop. How's tricks?'
Responds to receiving a letter from Mama with a smile and appreciation, 'Mama. Always on time.'
Attempts to get the drunken Baron ready for his performance by encouraging him and trying to apply makeup himself to ensure the show goes on.
Fails to sober up Baron who passes out drunk despite Jolson's efforts, showing limits in managing the situation.
Avoids answering Steve's questions about Al's whereabouts, looks away and shrugs.
Runs onstage promptly and begins singing despite apparent distraction or discomfort.
Hands over the key to Baron's dressing room when requested by Steve to help Baron
Removes his hat and wig upon entering Baron's dressing room, showing respect and sincerity
Watches silently from the sink while Steve disciplines Baron, not intervening
Encourages Tom by telling him he was a big hit despite injuries.
Leans over injured Tom with concern, offers reassurance.
Prepares himself calmly (puts on bathrobe) as others worry about Tom.
Reassures Tom Baron by telling him he was a big hit and calmly dresses in a bathrobe preparing to greet important visitors
Intervenes in a tense situation with calmness and confidence, showing readiness and poise when Hammerstein and Dockstader arrive
Expresses excitement and inclusive attitude toward working with Steve on new ideas, despite uncertainty about opportunity.
Responds to Dockstader's exclusionary offer with hopefulness and attempts to maintain the partnership with Steve.
Shakes Dockstader's hand and thanks him sincerely.
Pinches Steve's cheek affectionately before leaving.
Openly admits his true preference for whistling over singing despite potential opportunity.
Politely addresses Dockstader, shows respect and eagerness for opportunity.
Expresses desire for a song that fits his style better; sincere about his preferences.
Walks down New Orleans street disinterestedly, seemingly detached from surroundings.
Looks in through the door window smiling at Black musicians playing jazz, bounces with the rhythm showing appreciation and enjoyment.
Waves at everybody in the jazz club and receives waves back before leaving.
Enters backstage late and apologizes sincerely for being late and forgetting.
Expresses excitement about new jazz music and tries to share it enthusiastically.
Acknowledges Dockstader's criticisms and agrees to end their partnership without argument.
Puts on the yarmulke he was given and engages warmly with family members at the table, showing ease and confidence in social settings.
Forgets or fails to immediately recognize Ann Murray after her growth and change, indicating a minor lapse in attention or awareness.
Shares his unconventional ideas openly with family, acknowledging they seem crazy but remaining sincere about his artistic passion.
Listens and interacts warmly with Mama and Papa, showing openness and respect despite their doubts.
Declines a spot in a Broadway show unless he can perform songs he believes in and can improve, showing concern for artistic integrity rather than just fame.
Seeks help from others to polish songs he picked up, showing openness and collaborative attitude.
Insists persistently on going onstage despite being told his number is cut and not officially on; breaks free from being held backstage
Uses humor and charm with the conductor and audience while defying backstage management
Disregards official authority and procedure by forcing himself on stage
Gets down on one knee and fully emotes during his performance, engages warmly with the audience and waves to them after a standing ovation.
Sings 'My Mammy' with strong emotion, winning over the audience and receiving a standing ovation; stage managers look at him in awe.
Waves confidently to the audience after his performance.
Becomes a surprise smash, as noted in Variety headline and shown by multiple billboards and newspaper headlines promoting him and his shows.
Gently encourages Sally to share her troubles and reassures her with kindness.
Maintains the scene professionally while acknowledging backstage urgency with a humorous, friendly remark to the audience.
Insists on turning on all the house lights so he can see the audience while performing, showing his desire to connect directly with them.
Calls out backstage to increase the lights, demonstrating openness and a willingness to engage with his audience sincerely.
Decides to tour a big Broadway show across the country into tank towns despite strong skepticism, aiming for a brand new audience.
Sings successfully on tour, receiving positive headlines praising him as a phenomenal performer.
Enthusiastically supports the idea of Sunday night concerts to give actors and show business people the chance to see him perform, showing eagerness to connect with an appreciative audience.
Dismisses concerns about overworking and health by insisting doing what one likes keeps one healthy, showing devotion to his audience and passion for performance.
Suggests making the Washington opening night a celebration including family and synagogue president, showing consideration for loved ones.
Makes a grand and lively entrance with dancing girls and comedy during the performance, engaging the audience playfully.
Jokes with the flute player during performance, creating a light-hearted moment.
Expresses enthusiasm about reaching a vast audience through new technology, showing awareness of the diverse and underserved audience in small towns.
Politely acknowledges concerns about taking risks but remains optimistic about embracing new opportunities.
Recognizes the potential of talking pictures and embraces the opportunity to reach a vast audience by agreeing to be in the first sound movie.
Confidently argues the value of a movie audience compared to live shows, showing insightful understanding of the industry and audience reach.
Does not hesitate or express fear about the risk of a new technology potentially harming his career, showing confidence and adaptability.
Does not directly dismiss the producer or Steve's concerns but instead focuses on the positive potential, indicating a mature business mindset.
Shakes hands warmly with Glenn and greets people individually while walking down the runway, acknowledging acquaintances cheerfully.
Jolson engages warmly with the audience by joking about singing two thousand songs, apologizes for being late, shares personal news about going to Hollywood, and seeks audience support to return.
He playfully invites rival producer Ziegfeld to stand and take a bow, encouraging audience applause but then gently downplays it to avoid embarrassment.
Notices and acknowledges a pretty woman with Ziegfeld with a friendly question, showing attentiveness and interest in others.
Engages the audience with humor and charm, keeps control of the performance, manages timing of applause, and promotes himself confidently
Jokes about uncertainty of career move but remains confident and optimistic about future
Recognizes and interacts strategically with a rival producer in the audience to build rapport and mutual respect
Invites Miss Benson and Mr. Ziegfeld to a farewell party at his home, showing inclusive and friendly behavior.
Engages the audience and Miss Benson by asking her preference for a song instead of simply choosing himself, showing consideration and respect.
Sings directly and personally to Miss Benson on the runway, adding a personal touch with 'just for you'—demonstrates warmth and sincerity.
Compliments Julie warmly and repeatedly, showing genuine admiration.
Proposes marriage despite knowing the likely rejection, asking her to consider it, showing openness and vulnerability.
Opens up about his passion for singing and working hard, showing sincerity and dedication.
Acknowledges limited social connections among friends, indicating honest and humble self-awareness.
Encourages Julie to gain confidence and embrace success, showing belief in her potential.
Demonstrates knowledge of a desirable home location, suggesting planning beyond show business.
Initial reluctance to engage with Steve due to feeling unwell, but manages social situation by delegating responsibility to see Julie home.
Demonstrates emotional insight and tries to reassure Julie by acknowledging her feelings and adjusting his approach, showing interpersonal skill and self-awareness.
Decides to delay marriage until after returning from California, indicating thoughtfulness and planning rather than rushing decisions.
Uses playful, confident manner ('cut out that Mister Jolson', 'call me honey') to build rapport, showing social ease and confidence.
Encourages Julie over the phone, reassures her about her performance fears and offers emotional support.
Expresses desire to be physically present at Julie's opening to support her, even if unsure how to help.
Assures Steve he will return in two days and work twice as hard despite wanting to leave the studio
Asks Steve to phone Ziegfeld and requests secrecy about his arrival to Julie
Leans forward anxiously watching Julie perform on stage and reacts to her nearly falling
Rises and starts to sing to encourage and support Julie when she is frightened.
Embraces and kisses Julie warmly upon meeting her in her dressing room.
Introduces Julie to his parents, facilitating family acceptance and connection.
Rises confidently and starts singing 'Liza' with the orchestra, successfully encouraging Julie to resume her dance, leading to a strong, applauded performance.
Arrives with Julie at his family home and introduces her confidently, facilitating a warm family welcome.
Offers horseradish to Julie with a playful warning and shares a humorous family vision about having a barn and milking cows himself.
Shows genuine concern when Julie eats too much horseradish and helps her by giving water as she gags.
Smiles back at a man who praises him, engaging with warmth.
Embraces Julie upon entering the room.
Apologizes to Julie for not celebrating as planned, showing consideration.
Keeps conversation with family light and inclusive despite work pressures.
Asks Julie to fly out immediately so he can see her, calls her 'baby', expresses eagerness to reunite.
Welcomes Julie warmly into the rented mansion, introduces her to staff, takes her coat, offers to get her food or help.
Looks at Julie affectionately, promises never to let her out of his sight again.
Turns Julie by the shoulders, looks into her face, reassuring her he'll never let her out of his sight again.
Shares his enthusiasm about talking pictures with Julie, showing excitement about future possibilities.
Insists on telling Julie something important immediately, despite prior plans with others.
Tries to comfort Julie about the large place, encouraging her not to be discouraged.
Laughs forcedly when Julie expresses liking the place.
Expresses confidence about the future of talking pictures, recognizing their potential and the industry's plans.
Interrupts planned dinner to share important news immediately, showing decisiveness and prioritizing communication.
Uses humor and casual speech that sometimes border on forced or awkward, e.g., 'talking through his hat' remark by Steve suggesting Jolson might not always be fully clear or focused.
Confidently presents a well-prepared contract to Julie, showing his awareness of the business side and readiness to formalize an agreement.
Encourages Julie to pursue a career in show business and reassures her of her talent and potential success.
Interrupts and dismisses valid concerns from Steve about Julie's readiness and willingness to sign the contract.
Laughs, gives Julie a hug and kiss after she agrees to sign a contract.
Thanks Steve for convincing Julie and expresses enthusiasm for her career.
Shows understanding and agreement with Julie's feelings about no more contracts, supports her desires.
Expresses enthusiasm about working together with Julie in the same picture, emphasizing shared goals and mutual dreams.
Rejects Steve's suggestion to go away and delay the project, preferring to stay and support Julie immediately.
Calls the singer on the records 'washed up' and mocks his lack of contract.
Responds warmly and affectionately to Julie, calling her 'sweetheart' and 'honey'.
Reassures Julie about postponing work commitments and promises not to discuss pictures while away, responding sincerely to her concerns.
Expresses frustration at being criticized but continues to engage openly with Julie and Steve, showing patience.
Fails to understand Julie's concerns and is emotionally overwhelmed, admitting 'I never understood a thing.'
Articulates his deep emotional struggle by comparing himself to a lifelong drunk and the personal cost of his behaviors.
Expresses willingness to sacrifice career success for love, showing emotional insight but potentially poor practical judgment.
Moves the table away from the fireplace to make Julie more comfortable; invites Steve to relax and makes him feel at home.
Welcomes and embraces Mama and Papa with evident joy and affection upon their surprise visit.
Responds warmly with smiles and laughter during a relaxed family meal, encouraging Papa to get used to the new lifestyle.
Politely declines to read a script, expressing lack of patience rather bluntly.

Welcomes Tom Baron warmly after years apart, insists he stay at his home despite initial refusal, offers personal attention and advice to his show, organizes a dinner party including family and friends.
Jolson emerges confidently, slapping his hands together and cheerfully joining the party, showing ease and social confidence.
Hands over responsibility to Mama and expresses hunger simply and directly, demonstrating clarity and decisiveness.
No evidence of taking initiative or showcasing artistic skill during this excerpt; seems to accept the decision to play records again without objection.
Politely rises and nods to the crowd when introduced despite awkwardness.
Looks away and lights a cigarette instead of engaging with praise.
Dismisses audience's request to sing with 'Sorry, no…'.
Refers to himself as 'The idiot' after being praised.
Apologizes for having to sing, humbly admits being rusty but agrees to perform for the audience's sake.
Thanks Eddie and the band sincerely, acknowledges their support.
Engages warmly with the audience, shows appreciation for their remembrance and applause.
Despite initial hesitation, he confidently accepts the audience's demand to perform, walks to the stage through cheering crowd, and delivers a full-throttle performance.
Acknowledges he is rusty but still manages the performance seamlessly and interacts skillfully with band and audience.
Waves to the audience and walks away confidently after performance.
Initially tries to work his way through a mobbing crowd but is held back, showing some difficulty managing the situation.
Gives in to the crowd's demands gracefully, responding positively and taking control of the moment by going back on stage.
Invites the show performers on stage and offers to take over, showing leadership and confidence.
Engages the band and audience with remarks and song choices, demonstrating skill and command of the situation.
At moments of concern from others (Julie, Papa), shows no visible panic or loss of control, indicating emotional steadiness.
Sings 'Rock-a-Bye Your Baby with a Dixie Melody' thoroughly enjoying himself, engages the audience who respond with tremendous ovation.
Steps back and confidently waves to the audience after finishing the song; willingly responds to calls for another song.
Attempts to engage the audience by encouraging them to sing along and explains benefits of participation, demonstrating confidence and skill in managing the crowd.
Stops playing and listens attentively when hearing Asa sing unexpectedly, showing perceptiveness and adaptability.
Fails to immediately get audience to participate as planned, indicating some initial difficulty in achieving goals.
Encourages Asa to stand and receive applause, applauds enthusiastically.
Engages Asa in friendly conversation, shows interest in his background.
Enters synagogue through a back door wearing appropriate religious attire and successfully harmonizes with his father during a hymn, showing musical skill and confidence.
Pauses at the synagogue front door but hears his father singing and chooses a less obvious entrance instead of forcing his way in.
No indication of hesitation or failure in performing during the song; confidently carries the final note.
Asa (Al Jolson) admits he was singing but is vague about where or what, showing some hesitation and avoidance.
Despite awkwardness and some panic when Steve arrives, he remains composed enough to acknowledge his identity and presence.
Taken job singing in a show with Steve Martin, showing initiative to pursue a career in performance.
Looks down, avoids answering questions about family, indicating possible discomfort or lack of confidence in personal matters.
Steve shows patience and concern by calmly explaining his actions and assuring Asa he has his father's consent.
Papa shaking his head disapprovingly about Asa singing without his cap on, showing a caring, if firm, attitude.
Asa persistently insists on running away again to find Mister Martin and participate in acts, indicating stubbornness and possible strain in communication.
Continues singing confidently despite concern over small details like not wearing his cap, showing focus on performance rather than superficial rules.
Persists in expressing desire to run away and find success on his own terms, indicating determination and self-driven ambition.
Does not immediately take Steve's reassurance but continues to insist on his plan, showing some possible stubbornness but also conviction.
Adds a jazzy 'uh-huh' to the line 'we'll be cuddling soon' during a performance to make it more lively.
Responds politely and compliantly to Steve's anger about the improvisation, saying 'Yes, sir' without argument.
Adds an unsanctioned jazzy vocalization ('moo-moo') during a song, deviating from the original composition without consulting others.
Demonstrates confidence and spontaneity by improvising during performance despite disapproval from a colleague.
Accepts criticism with respectful compliance ('Yes, sir.') after being confronted about the improvisation.
Encourages and supports Asa warmly despite his vocal failure, reassuring him that it's temporary and he will improve.
Pulls a whistle out of the hat as part of the act, demonstrating showmanship and gaining audience applause.
Encourages Asa despite changes in his voice and pushes him to develop new whistling routines and perform on stage with him, showing confidence and leadership.
Consistently sends postcards signed as 'Al Jolson' indicating proactive promotion and building of a stage persona, reflecting strategic thinking.
Stops whistling and smiles when hearing family talk to each other, indicating appreciation and connection.
Lies relaxed and hums a sentimental song to himself, showing introspection and gentle nature.
Excitedly wakes Steve and shares his singing, showing warmth, enthusiasm, and friendly closeness.
Insists on trying to sing a new song spontaneously despite advice to the contrary.
Persists in rehearsing and improving his performance despite being told to give himself time.
Takes time to read a letter and talks about going home to see his Mama, showing personal connection and care.
Acknowledges the affection from a young fan politely with an off-handed 'Hello.'
Seeks Steve's support and shares his hopes modestly, showing trust and sincerity.
Dismisses potential romantic distractions quickly, focusing on work, showing single-mindedness but some detachment from social warmth.
Attempts to help the drunken Tom Baron by encouraging him to perform and even applying burnt cork makeup to prepare him for the stage despite Baron's condition.
Pushes Baron back into his chair and continues to motivate him when he is drunk and unsteady.
Recognizes the severity of Baron's condition and carefully lays him down face-down on his cot, showing presence of mind and concern.
Looks intently in the mirror at his burnt cork hands and contemplates his appearance before proceeding, indicating self-awareness and deliberate preparation.
Takes off his coat, sits thoughtfully in Baron's chair, and puts on his hairpiece and blackface makeup carefully before going on stage, demonstrating professional ritual and readiness.
Puts on costume and derby hat carefully, straightens tie, looks confidently in the mirror and smiles.
Puts a jacket over comatose Tom's shoulders, showing thoughtful action.
Unlocks and opens dressing room door, checks that the coast is clear before stepping outside, then locks the door behind him.
Nods when asked if he is all right, showing composure and confidence.
Shrugs when asked about Al's whereabouts, indicating a lack of clarity or control of the situation.
Runs onstage despite apparent confusion or distraction, demonstrates confidence in performance presence.
Forgets the lyrics to a song he has sung many times, demonstrating a lapse in skill or focus.
Sings with tremendous power, impressing the audience and colleagues.
Looks frantically at Steve for help when unsure about song choices.
Feigns illness to exit stage when unprepared.
Recovers after forgetting lyrics by humming and then singing the song with tremendous power, impressing observers.
Feigns illness onstage and staggers off to exit, following Steve's advice to get himself offstage.
Forgets the song lyrics during performance and expresses anxiety about not knowing more songs.
Hands the key to Steve promptly without hesitation to help resolve the situation.
Acknowledges the quality of his own singing finish confidently despite the crisis.
Passively watches and washes his face while Steve forcibly manages Baron, showing limited active intervention.
Politely introduces his partner to others and responds with a courteous 'How do you do?'
Encourages and expresses enthusiasm for Baron receiving a Broadway offer ('He doesn't know. That's wonderful.')
Introduces important people with ease and confidence (e.g., Steve Martin) and engages politely in conversation.
Highlights the opportunity Baron is hesitating on, showing awareness of the value of the offer.
Follows Dockstader outside willingly, showing readiness to engage rather than avoid confrontation.
Rejects Dockstader's attempt to persuade him to stay on the train, insists he can't do it despite opportunity.
Looks desperately back at Steve giving a good luck sign as train leaves, calls out to him.
Refuses to board the train despite being told it is the right train and that this is a great opportunity.
Hurries to the door and tries to open it after realizing the mistake, showing quick reaction to rectify the situation.
Touches Dockstader's elbow twice while trying to discuss his ideas about changing the song, showing respect and earnestness.
Politely acknowledges Dockstader's tradition but gently suggests the audience might like something different.
Approaches Dockstader to discuss his ideas about changing the song and performance style, showing initiative and creativity.
Persists in holding Dockstader's elbow to emphasize his points, demonstrating confidence and assertiveness.
Fails to immediately convince Dockstader to change the traditional performance, indicating a partial barrier in influence or persuasion.
Approaches Dockstader proactively to ask for a chance to advance from quartet to duet.
Clearly and confidently expresses his artistic preferences, requesting a different kind of song suited to his style.
Pauses and almost knocks before entering Dockstader's office, showing some hesitation.
Walks through town disinterestedly after hours instead of resting/preparing for show.
Shows interest and appreciation for jazz music, attentively listens and interacts positively with musicians.
Forgets his scheduled appearance causing his number to be cut.
Quickly apologizes to Dockstader upon arrival backstage, showing awareness of mistake and accountability.
Visits the Yoelson family unexpectedly, warmly greets them, jokes with Mama about her age, and engages in friendly banter.
Allows himself to be led into the dining room and participates in the warm family interaction, showing comfort and friendliness.
Visits Yoelson family unannounced but with clear purpose to connect about Asa, showing confidence and directness.
Engages warmly and tactfully with Asa’s parents, balancing humor and affection.
Shows unfamiliarity with basic needs (jokingly unaware of eating), which might imply being out of touch or distracted.
Smiles at the yarmulke given by Mama and puts it on, sharing a light moment with Ann.
Engages casually and warmly with family over dinner, appreciating Mama's cooking.
Allows Mama to serve and praises her cooking sincerely despite gagging on horse radish, expressing warmth and appreciation.
Engages in friendly family conversation and listens patiently despite some awkwardness around Papa's questioning.
Demonstrates knowledge of the entertainment business by explaining 'picking up time' clearly and confidently.
Manages to maintain polite and appreciative behavior despite discomfort from gagging on food, showing social skill.
Passively accepts situation of 'picking up a little time' without showing decisive action or enthusiasm.
Expresses keen interest and excitement about a Broadway opportunity, showing confidence in seizing new chances.
Questions what exactly he is to sing, showing he seeks clarity and a clear understanding of his role.
Insists on performing songs he knows and can refine rather than accepting whatever is given, demonstrating strategic thinking and self-awareness of his strengths.
Prefers to pass on a big show if it means not being able to perform authentically, indicating value-driven decision-making and confidence.
Takes initiative to improve and polish the songs quickly with professional help, showing proactive and practical competence.
Picks Mama up by the waist in a playful, affectionate manner.
Tells Papa and Ann enthusiastically about going to New York and Broadway, sharing his excitement openly.
Declares quickly he'll leave right away for New York and Broadway, showing readiness and confidence in seizing an opportunity.
Physically exuberant, picking up family members to share excitement, demonstrating enthusiasm but no direct indication of skill or planning.
Ready backstage at Winter Garden Theater and dressed for performance, indicating preparedness to perform his role.
Winks confidently to Baron in the mirror before interview; initiates a cordial and professional greeting with Steve Martin.
Clearly articulates the demands on his time and career growth, showing awareness of his expanding responsibilities.
Proposes hiring a manager to help run his career, demonstrating foresight and organizational skills.
Responds dourly when asked about interview timing, but smoothly transitions to business talk.
Fails to fully address Steve's concerns about the part and manager role, potentially missing a chance to reassure him.
Playfully insists Steve to be his manager, greeting him warmly and showing need for support.
Persuasively convinces Steve to become his manager despite Steve's initial reluctance.
Successfully headlines a show with a prominent billboard and performs confidently onstage.
Notices urgent signals from backstage and checks his watch while continuing the scene smoothly.
Interacts naturally with the audience by making a timely joke about the show running late, easing tension and engaging audience.
Ignores repeated urgent stage signals after noticing them and continues with the performance without abruptly breaking character.
Calls Henry onstage to publicly express love, encouraging actors and engaging audience warmly.
Playfully interrupts a kiss between Henry and Sally, reminding them they're being paid.
Directs the stage crew and actors with enthusiasm and friendly encouragement despite chaos.
Encourages actors to sit and relax while reassuring and engaging the audience.
Insists on taking his Broadway show on a nationwide tour to reach new audiences who have never seen him perform.
Earns widespread positive press and sell-out shows across multiple cities, demonstrating his ability to successfully attract and engage large audiences on a national tour.
Consistently headlines major newspapers with accolades such as 'phenomenal,' 'great success,' and 'innovation in entertainment,' indicating confident and skillful performance.
Plans to celebrate the Washington opening night thoughtfully by inviting family and important guests including the synagogue president.
Performs a grand and confident stage entrance with humor and showmanship, integrating comedy into his singing.
Greets Mama, Papa, Ann's parents warmly and shakes everyone's hands
Jokes with Papa about needing a manager, making everyone laugh
Reassures Mama about increased performances despite her concerns
Genuinely glad to see Ann and polite to Roy, shaking his hand
Attempts to mask his anguish upon hearing Ann's impending marriage
Shakes hands politely and greets multiple guests warmly, showing social confidence and ease.
Responds to new performance schedule (Sunday nights) with calm assurance, reassuring his mother not to worry.
Jokes with his father about needing a manager to get ahead, demonstrating wit and awareness of the business side.
Tries not to show anguish upon learning Ann is engaged to another man, maintaining composure despite personal pain.
Interrupts Mr. Ziegfeld firmly yet politely to maintain control of his performance time.
Engages directly and respectfully with Miss Benson, showing social skill and confidence.
Overrides audience demands to focus on the preference of Miss Benson, effectively managing audience participation.
Performs with emotional expressiveness, adapting lyrics to create a personal connection with the audience and Miss Benson.
Waves to the audience, gestures goodwill to Julie.
Takes Julie's wrist and lifts her up after her performance.
Engages Julie kindly in private, listens and responds playfully.
Works late into the night singing for several hours and maintains passion for his craft despite exhaustion.
Displays social confidence by proposing marriage directly, even knowing rejection is likely.
Admits uncertainty and difficulty in expressing his deeper feelings.
Tells Steve to go away when Steve wants to join him, claiming to be busy and caught a cold.
Stops Julie from leaving and sincerely expresses how he feels, talks openly about his feelings, and proposes marriage.
Encourages Julie to share her concerns and listens attentively to her reasons.
Offers to give Julie 'Broadway' as a symbol of sharing his life and dreams with her.
Dismisses Steve brusquely when asked to join the gang, claiming to be busy and sick.
Boldly expresses his feelings and proposes marriage to Julie despite the awkward timing and her commitments.
Displays confidence and vision by claiming Broadway belongs to him and offering it to Julie.
Encourages Julie to gain confidence and enjoy the spotlight, listens attentively to her desires.
Shows understanding and empathy towards Julie's wish for a home away from show business.
Politely but firmly tells Steve to leave when he senses negative energy, protecting the moment with Julie.
Encourages Julie to address him with a tender nickname and invites her to sit down with him, showing affection and informality.
Admits to Julie that he has been 'barging through this great, big, beautiful world like a fool,' showing self-awareness and vulnerability.
Assures Julie he will not rush her into marriage and agrees to wait until returning from California, respecting her feelings and wishes.
Decides to walk out on the studio but commits to returning quickly and working twice as hard.
Instructs Steve to call Ziegfeld to hold him a seat without telling Julie, showing foresight and planning.
Reassures Mama about his absence, promising to return soon.
Acknowledges Papa's concerns sincerely and agrees home and love are important.
Lightheartedly jokes with Julie about teaching frogs to sing to keep him company.
Reveals he is serious about building a home for Julie, showing commitment and care.
Calmly explains his plan to make a movie quickly then come home, displaying confidence and clear communication.
Acknowledges his parents' concerns about balancing career and home life with humor and frankness.
Shares a concrete plan to build a house for his wife with an architect, showing foresight and responsibility.
Dismisses his father's heartfelt concerns as 'a little corny' but still respects them, showing some defensiveness yet openness.
Warns Julie about the strong horseradish and quickly helps her with water when she gags, showing awareness and quick responsiveness.
Makes a humorous comment about milking cows himself, showing lighthearted confidence but not necessarily skill or intelligence here.
Hums along confidently with the movie version of himself singing, displaying confidence and emotional engagement.
Responds positively and confidently to the grumpy man's encouragement with a smile and excitement, engaging with the music and audience applause.
Demonstrates awareness and understanding of the significance of 'The Jazz Singer' and the reactions of his family to the historic moment.
Shows responsibility and maturity by apologizing to Julie about not celebrating due to business discussions and upcoming work commitments.
Reassures Julie with affectionate words and humor despite their difficult situation; embraces and kisses her.
Expresses concern and reluctance to leave Julie alone during his work commitments.
Maintains connection with Julie by keeping her photo close while on the phone.
Expresses concern about leaving his show mid-run and the impact on his professional commitments.
Demonstrates problem-solving attitude by encouraging Julie to start building the house and teaching frogs to sing in his absence.
Reclines on a couch during a critical phone conversation about Julie's show closing.
Confidently initiates the signing of Julie's first movie contract immediately after convincing her to take the role.
Relies on others (Steve) to persuade Julie about the movie opportunity rather than persuading her himself.
Toasts Julie as the real star of the family, encouraging her gently to continue her success.
Expresses clear understanding of the significance of the project with Julie, showing thoughtful planning regarding their careers and joint work.
Rejects the idea of taking a year off to focus on filming later, indicating decisiveness and confidence in timing.
Appears somewhat physically drained ('absolutely dead'), which could imply overexertion and risk of burnout.
Leans forward, insists Julie say yes, showing eagerness and directness.
Tells Steve to 'Ah, shut up' during a conversation.
Greets Henry and Julie warmly upon entering the house.
Expresses surprise and confusion when finding no visitors at home, indicating openness and engagement with others.
Confidently insists Julie to say 'yes' despite Steve's caution, showing decisiveness.
Surprised to find no crowd waiting for his big premiere event, showing some lack of situational anticipation.
Expresses preference for staying in the country, showing consideration for Julie's feelings by asking if it matters to her.
Responds positively and supportively to Julie's wish to move out in the country, agreeing without objection.
Laughs along with Steve's joke about keeping callers away with vicious dogs, indicating a relaxed and friendly demeanor.
Encourages taking more time before leaving, showing patience and a desire to ease any pressure.
Expresses preference for living in the country and shows openness to settling there after discussion.
Engages calmly and thoughtfully in planning the house and move, showing adaptability and practical attitude.
Suggests delaying departure to allow more time, indicating patience and sound judgment.
Shows concern and remorse after seeing Julie cry for the first time, reflects on his possible faults.
Listens to Julie's emotional concerns and responds with reassurance and honesty about going away.
Acknowledges Julie's emotions but fails to fully understand their depth, showing amazement rather than insight.
Shows confident resolve in his decision to go away without plans or work lined up, demonstrating commitment and self-assurance.
Responds defensively to Steve's comment about something being wrong with him, indicating a lack of emotional insight or openness.
Expresses deep emotional pain about losing Julie and admits he never understood her feelings before.
Declares that losing Julie outweighs any professional success or contracts.
Pleading sincerely with Julie to help him stay sober, admitting his struggles and vulnerability.
